Omnes/Both/Ambo

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

body.stage:
Act. I.
Enter Signior Antifront, with a Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Dear Lord, I know it well becomes not me to counsel him that best can counsel me : yet if it please you but to lend your ears, and hear my love if not my counsel.

sp.speaker: Sig.
sp.p: No more, I know thy love tends to the stopping of my longing and my resolution: thou knowest that I no longer now am Signior: Florence hath got another governor, and one step back in state of Majesty, is a greater fall than to a meaner man that loseth all: Besides, thou knowest our Daughters they are fled, the true inheritors of Florence right, and mighty Piso now usurps our regal seat: puissant in power and mighty in his wrong, hath mounted Falcon-like into the sky of state, seized on our feebleness, and beat our weakness down . And therefore now I am resolved to find my two lost Children out, or like as Phaeton in pride did ride, so I in grief will pace the world about.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Unto your celsitude I wish, till their effects your hopes may never fail.

sp.speaker: Sig.
sp.p: Farewell, some strange disguise I needs must take both for my stealth away, as for my passage on the way: and yet my fortunes fall, disguisement is too great if pleased the heavens, but their wills still are laws, all is but Justice and our sins the cause: cuor forte rompe catiua sorte.

body.stage: Enter Florida, and Felecia, Daughters to Signior Antifront, Madam Fromaga their waiting Gentlewoman, and two or three Seruingmen.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: With draw, leave us , we would be private: Sister what think you of this trade of ours?

body.stage: Exeunt all but the two Sisters

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: It is base to be a whore.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: It is base to abuse great place, or baseness to deceive great trust.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: And is it not baseness to abuse great birth?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yes if great birth abused not us : if Piso had not proved the thief and robbed us of our right, it had been worse than theft in us to rob ourselves of honour: you will say we are forbid to live by sin, and yet we are commanded seek to live: the letter law express forbids to kill, and yet the sense permits it rather than be killed: and since of two extremities the least is to be chosen, you know we have no other means to live, but had we , yet we are fair by nature, scorning Art, and was not beauty made to be enjoyed? do we not exclaim on those who have abundant store of Coin, and yet for want suffer the needy perish at their door? so might all do on us, having so much beauty, if we should suffer men for love of us to die; shall we in whom beauty keeps her court be curbed and tide to one man's benevolence? no, no, not I: rather than in virtue to live poor, in sin I will die.

sp.speaker: Fele.
sp.p:
Your resolutions hath confirmed my doubts, and since it is hateful to live poor, to maintain our state I am content: but these observances let us keep, strangely amongst strangers let us hold our state, and let our Servants seldom know, how familiar with our friends we be , and though Englands wealth do now adorn us; let us keep the fashion still of Florence.
Content, let us in, who is near? attend us , ho!

body.stage: Enter Fromaga, and Ladyes Exeunt. To her enter a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: This is the street, and as I remember this is the door. I will ask this ancient Gentlewoman: health and beauty dwell with you Lady.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: I thank you sir, he has a courtly phrase i'faith.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Do the Florentine Ladies dwell here ?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Yes forsooth sir, I am a poor Gentlewoman that follows them .

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I am sent to them by a Knight, who promised me he had procured me the place of a Gentleman Usher to them.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Haue-little I think.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Yes indeed the same.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: By my troth he is an honest Knight, he has no fault but that he is poor, and that is a small fault nowadays: but let me see sir I pray, were you never a Gentleman Usher before?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: No truly never yet.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Then you must be instructed sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I shall be glad to learn.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: I hope you and I shall be more inward sir, and for your instruction I shall be glad to lay open any secrets that I have ; therefore first you must observe: have you any Tables?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Yes, sure I never go without Tables.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Pluck out your pin and write down as I shall utter: to be always ready, standing bare, to be employed, when, where, and howsoever your Ladies please. You must never be without money of your own , to lay out when your Ladies bid you, as eighteen pence to the Porter, half a Crown to the Coachman, or twelve pence for a torch if their Ladyships come home late at night. If you be sent by your Lady to another Lady, to know what rest she took in the night, you shall deliver your answer just as it came from the Lady: you must always be in a clean band, and clean cusses, how foul so ever your shirt be.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I will observe all this.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: You may by virtue of your office wear a Periwig, provided it be just of the colour of your beard: let me see, you have a hatched sword of your own there, have ye not?

sp.speaker: Gent,
sp.p: Yes forsooth, I bought it for his Ladyships service.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: It was well done, you may wear it by your office, what, is your Cloak lined through?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: No, but it is of a good depth in.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: It is well done too, your Ladies love to have it Lined a good depth in, it is for their credit. What, are these silver hangers of your own ?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: No, I borrowed these, but I have a pair of mine own .

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: They are in trouble, are they?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: No truly they are at mending.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Nay though they be, it is no shame, you have been long out of service perchance.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Some three months.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Birlady it is a long time, but can you endure to walk some half a day in the Hall or the great Chamber, while some great Lord is busy with your Lady in an inner room? you may sleep an hour or two as your Citizens' wives do at a Sermon to pass away the time, but you must have a care to wake at the rushing of a Satin gown, or the creaking of a door, that if your Lady come, you may be presently up and bare.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Yes sure, I could do it well.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: You must stand stiff up , and hold up your head, it is the chiefest thing belongs to your place, look here comes the elder Lady: Madam here is the Gentleman that Sir Iohn Haue-little commended to your Ladyship for a Gentleman Usher.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Let him draw near us .

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: The Knight commends his dear affection, and by me makes tender of his humble service to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Kiss your hand and go forward upon her.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: We accept it, have red it, you are beholding to the knight, and he hath spared no pains to make your worthy parts well known to us : draw near us , hence forth we accept you as our own , and so we bid you welcome: are you a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Yes sure Madam, for I was both born and begotten in an Inns Court.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Sure Madam then he is a Gentleman, for he that is but admitted to the house is a Gent. much more he that is begotten in the house.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You are the more welcome, and our bounty shall deserve your industry.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Is the Lady a Princess that she speaks us and we so much?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: No, she says so meaning herself and her Sister, for they are both one, and such things as they have , they use in common, and must stand bare before them both: look here comes the the other Lady.
Madam here is the Gentleman that Sir Iohn Haue-little commended to your Ladyship for a Gentleman Usher.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: We like him and he is welcome, what good parts have you? have you the tongues?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Not very well Madam.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Yes Madam, he has the Scottish tongue very perfectly, and he has some skill in the Irish tongue too.

sp.speaker: Fe:
sp.p: that is a wild speech.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Nay I will warrant your Ladyship he will not run away, has travelled Madam too he says, for he has been in Wales.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: Has he no skill in the French tongue?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Some little skill Madam.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: No sure Madam, I think your Ladyship hath more knowledge of the French than he.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: Well, we will at more leisure survey your good parts, and make thereof the best for our own use.

sp.speaker: Gent,
sp.p: I pray ye what wages do these Ladies give?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p:
Faith your wages will be much about the nature of your office, very bare standing wages: I think some
forty shillings a year.

sp.speaker: Gent
sp.p: Why, how mean they I shall live in their service?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Why, by their countenance: I have known a Lord hath given his fool nothing but his countenance to live by, and I can tell you, it has proved a good Court-maintenance too.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Countenance? I hope I have a countenance good enough of mine own , I need not serve for one.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: In troth and so he has for a Gentleman usher, I must needs say a very harmless silly countenance.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Yet faith I mean to try their bounty.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Come will you walk in sir? I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Very willingly.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: This is brave i'faith, he shall go bare before me too, he will serve us all three when we are abroad.

body.stage:
Exeunt.
Enter Mistresse Susan, and Nan, sisters:

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: Come sister, come, we were not born to stand, it is against the nature of our sexes kind: come, sit, and tell me, how many suitors you have , and which you most do love? and I will tell you all mine, and which I most respect.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p:
Faith I have a dozen at the least, and their deserts are all so good, I know not which I should love most: and one last day did court me thus: O had my tongue the influence to lead thy fair thoughts as thy fair looks do mine: then shouldst thou be his prisoner who is thine. I seeing my poor Gentleman likely to be drowned in the depth of Hellespont, delivered him this verse to catch hold of:
O be not fair, and so unkind: misshapen stuff, is of behaviour boisterous and rough.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: But come, what was he for a man?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What was he for a man? Why, he was a man for a woman, what should he be? and i'faith he was a neat lad too, for his beard was newly cut bare; marry it showed something like a Meadow newly mowed: stubble, stubble.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: Well I have a suitor too, if he&Htp; had as much wit as living, it may be I should find in my heart to love him.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What, is it Sir Iohn Haue-little that gallant Knight that Courts delicate Ladies? spare not the sweat of my body, man was made to labour, use my creation, women to bear, I will use yours: Birds to fly, Fish to swim, etcetera And then swears by my conscience Lady, I esteem you as I do money, which buys everything , and that is but like a Punk, for every man has to do with it.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: No Sister no, it is not he, for I think his wit cannot call his wealth Master, nor his wealth his wit, and yet they are both Servants to a fool.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Faith who is it Sister, is it a proper man? hath he&Htp; a good face?

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: It is the person and conditions I respect, and not face, for every Boy has a good face, and it is not worth a hair. No Sister no, my love is more worthier than words can utter: I cannot sympathise his rare perfections with any earthy substance: this Globe of dirt produceth nothing worthy of his comparison, so soul's perfection so refines his body, as you would think an Angel were his sire: his discourse, behaviour, and humanity, attracts to him my soul's felicity.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Pray heaven it be not mine: nay come who is your love? tell me?

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: Nay who is yours? speak first.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Yet again !

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: If it be mine, my heart will break: mine is Master

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Who, who, who?

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: Ruffell.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Pray God it be true.

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: In troth it is he.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: And mine is Master Sparke, and look here they come.

body.stage: Enter Spark, Ruffell, Piso, Knight, and Petoune.

sp.speaker: Spar.
sp.p: Faith Ladies, youth and beauty always be your handmaids.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Best fortunes your attendants.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Good clothes your companions.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: We all of us your servants.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And let Tobacco be your perfumes.

sp.speaker: Nan,
sp.p: Lord Gentlemen how your wits Caper! methinks it would become you well at first entrance, your discretions came in with a sober measure.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Ladies we are come to make a Gentleman of your acquaintance here .

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: His name good Master Spark? he is very welcome.

sp.speaker: Spar,
sp.p: His name is Seignior. Petoune a Traveller and a great Tobacconist.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Faith Ladies I take it now and then fasting for the purification of my wit.

sp.speaker: Sus:
sp.p: Purification? why has your wit lain in child-bed sir?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Yes indeed Lady, brought to bed of a Moon calf.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Faith Ladies if you used but mornings when ye rise, the divine smoke of this Celestial herb, it will more purify, cleanse and mundify your complexions, by ten parts than your dissolved Mercury, your juice of Lemons, your distilled snails, your gourd waters, your oil of tartar, or a thousand such toys.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Sure Ladies I must needs say the instinct of this herb hath wrought in this Gentleman such a divine influence of good words, excellent discourse, admirable invention, incomparable wit: why I tell ye , when he talks, wisdom stands a mile off and dares not come near him, for fear he should shame her: but before he did use this Tobacco, he was the arrantest Woodcock that ever I saw.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Indeed I was a very silly fellow.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Nay you were an arrant ass.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Sure I was a fool.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Nay, you were a most monstrous puppy.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Indeed I was an Idiot, a very Idiot.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: By this light thou wert a most egregious coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Indeed I was, indeed I was.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: But since, it hath embellished his good parts, perfected his ill parts, and made his secrete actions correspondent to his outward wisdom, as you may well perceive.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Faith Lady these Gentlewomen have not long used my company, yet you see how Tobacco hath already refined their spirits.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Petoune I wonder Tobacco hath not purified the complexion of thy nose?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why, what ails my nose?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Nay, be not angry, I do not touch thy nose, to the end he should take anything in snuff.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why do ye play so about my nose?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: It is a good turn he is no Fly seignior: if he were, he would burn his wings.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: O seignior, these Gentlewomen have not long used your company, yet you see how Tobacco hath already refined their spirits.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.p: Fayth Lady, would you bestow but one favour of me.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Truly seignior if you should have as much favour as you have complexion, you would be highly favoured.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Dear Lady, now by this day I love you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Cheap seignior, now by the light of this day, I cannot love you.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Now Lady, what drugs of wit has this Apothecary of Tobacco sold you?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Faith he sold me none sir, only he gave me a taste of his good meaning.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Faith Lady I must enquire your name.

sp.speaker: Sus:
sp.p: I pray ye do sir, yond Gentlewoman knows it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: O, I know it well enough .

sp.speaker: Svs.
sp.p: Why do you enquire it then?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Come, come, Lady can you love?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Aye .

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And can you love me?

sp.speaker: Sus:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Every fool can say, Aye , and no,

sp.speaker: Sus:
sp.p: And I always answer every fool so.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Do ye think I want wit?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: If you do, it is a shame you do not learn it.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Will you teach me? I will come to you to school.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: It is not my profession sir, to teach a fool.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Look, look, this fellow is like your upright shoo, he will serve either foot.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Good Lady, have a better regard of me, do but think me made of the same metal other men are.

sp.speaker: Sus:
sp.p: If others were of the same metal you are, and all mine, I should quickly sell them to the Bell-makers.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why, what metal do you think me?

sp.speaker: Sus:
sp.p: Copper sir, copper, for I take your body to be of the same metal your nose is.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Dear Lady, now by this day I love you.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Why, how now seignior, what says the Lady will she love thee man?

sp.speaker: Pet;
sp.p: Faith I can get but a cold comfort of her:

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Well thank her for it :

sp.speaker: Pet;
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Sp,
sp.p: Why, for her cold comfort, she&Htp; gave it thee to cool the heat of thy nose man?

sp.speaker: Sus:
sp.p: Seignior, you see these Gentlewomen have not long used your company; yet you see how Tobacco hath already refined their spirits:

sp.speaker: Ruf;
sp.p: Why, how now seignior? at blind-man-buff? bobbed on either side?

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Prithee peace: dear Lady, please you take a pipe of Tobacco?

sp.speaker: Ruf:
sp.p: Aye , come: I will begin to her ( tab ) why, what a rogue art thou to offer a fair Lady an empty pipe?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Why seignior? do you make a fool of me?

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: Had you nobody seignior to have bobbed with an empty Pipe but her?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Why how now seignior, could you find never a fitter block to whet your wit on, but my sister?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: By the divine smoke of Tobacco seignior, you have shamed us all.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Swear not good sir, swear not, profane not the Indian plant.

sp.speaker: Kni,
sp.p: Had you nobody else seignior, to break an empty jest on but this Lady?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: No, no, he thinks anything is good enough for me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Sir, would you make my Lady and me friends?

sp.speaker: Spar.
sp.p: Nay seignior, I have no face to speak, now you have abused her in your own Element: if it had been in anything but Tobacco, I would have done my best.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Hark you seignior. you were best to ask her forgiveness on your knees, there is no way to get her friendship else.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: But will she forgive me think you if I ask her mercy on my knees?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Why, prove seignior, you can but try, we will all speak for you.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
Pet.
sp.p: Lady, I must confess I have offered you an empty pipe, which methinks hath small reason to be take in snuff.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: And you are sorry for it seignior, are you not?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Aye with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Forgive him good Lady, pray ye forgive him,

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: I am content Gent at your entreaties upon conditions.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.p: Upon any conditions.

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: But you shall be sworn to them.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Most willingly.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Come, he shall be sworn on his own Tobacco pipe.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: Look you seignior, he told you there was no way to get her good will but by kneeling; for he that will have a woman's love must stoop.

sp.speaker: Sus:
sp.p: Come master Ruff: you shall take his oath, and I will minister it .

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Come seignior, put your hand to the pipe.

sp.speaker: Sus:
sp.p: First you shall never while you live offer Lady or Gentlewoman an empty pipe.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Never .

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: Secondly, you shall never make Tobacco your Idol, taking it in a morning before you say your prayers.

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: Thirdly, you shall never in the praise of Tobacco disclose or dispraise by the way of making comparisons, the secrets of Ladies, or Gentlewomen, as repeating their distilled waters, their sensing oils, or their smoothing unguents.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: To this you swear.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Most willingly.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: Fourthly, you shall never come with your squibs and smoke-squirts amongst Ladies and Gentlewomen, flinging out fume at your Nostrils, as a whale doth salt-water, unless you be entreated by them.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Never .

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: Firstly, you shall presently convey yourself out of our company, never to come more near us , unless you be sent for.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Never ?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: No never : so, let him kiss the pipe.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Come Signior, you have kneeled to a fair end, to get you a Mistress, and here you have forsworn her.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I am in a fair case now.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: I'faith now thou art a comb for any case.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Well, I will keep my oath, farewell Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Farewell Signior.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Adieu Signior.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: God bewe Signior.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Well, some shall smoke for this.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Let it be your nose then good Signior in any case:

body.stage: Exit. Enter Signior Antifront disguised, called Fleire.

sp.p: It is a good soil, a wholesome air, a pretty Town, handsome sleight buildings, well proportioned people, very fair women.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Hayda, this is like a Lawyers study in the latter end of a Term, one is no sooner thrunged out, but another is thrust in, ye are welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: But I am not sir, for I am sick.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Would you speak with any man here ?

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: I care not greatly sir, if I spoke with every man here.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: He is a mad fellow.

sp.speaker: Sp;
sp.p: What art?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Poor.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Dost mean to live in this town?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: I would be loath to die in it .

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: In what country wert born?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: In none.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Where then?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: In a Town.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: What nation art?

sp.speaker: Flei:
sp.p: An Italian:

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: O then thou canst make glasses.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Aye , and as wise men as you Asses too, O are you there Piso? your father is my good Lord, but no more of that yet.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Why Signior, I hope you will not swagger?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: No, nor I care not greatly for them that do , for your swaggerer is but like your walking spur, he jingles much but he will never prick.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Why art so melancholy?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: I will hold my life he&Htp; is in love with some waiting Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: He is a mad fellow will love any of you all, longer than a pissing while.

sp.speaker: Pis:
sp.p: Why camest thou out of Italy into England?

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: Because England would not come into Italy to me?

sp.speaker: Pis:
sp.p: Why art sad?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Because I have cause.

sp.speaker: Pis:
sp.p: Who dost follow?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: My nose.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Who dost serve?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: God.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Who art towards?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: He that is before me.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: What dost want?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Money.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Nothing else?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sp,
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Flei.
sp.p: A good service.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Shall I prefer thee?

sp.speaker: Flei.
sp.p: I cannot tell, it is as I like the man.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Nay it shall be to a couple of Gentlewomen of thine own Country.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: I shall have enough to do then I hope, I have heard of one woman hath served ten men, but I never heard that one man should be preferred to serve two women before: ye are an Englishman.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Aye .

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: So I thought indeed, you cannot poison so well as we Italians, but you will find a means to bring a man out of his life as soon. Gods light serve two women quoth you?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Why thou shalt serve but one, yet take thy choice of both.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Aye marry Sir, I like when it comes to choosing.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Fleire.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: What is thy profession?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: I have ever been a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: A Courtier! come Gentlemen, I like this fellow so well that I will prefer him straight.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Do so, you shall do a deed of charity in it .

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Fair Ladies you will excuse us .

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: You have been very welcome Gentlemen

sp.speaker: Na:
sp.p: Come sister, there rests nothing for us now but this: we will get us men's apparel, and serve them as Pages so shall we hinder them in their marriages, and in the end prefer ourselves to be their wives.

sp.speaker: Su,
sp.p: I like it well, come let us about it presently.

body.stage:
Actus secundus.
Enter Fleire, Solus in a new Suite.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p:
I have not yet been seven days here , and yet I see that grieves my very soul: my Daughters, my Ladies I must say now, make lust, labour for their maintenance, and this foolish nation will sell their goods, their lands, nay their very souls for nights delights and momentary sports,
which like to lightning appears, and vanisheth ere one can say it is come: but then repentance sticks close. There was a fellow with one of my Ladies this morning, and the poor slave has but seven shillings a week board wages, and yet he has given six of it for a bit of extraordinary flesh, well: God give him the grace to pray, for he must fast. I asked the hot slave why he did not marry since he could not bridle his lust? and he told me he had rather fall into the Surgeon's mercy, than the world's beggary; well, I see it cannot be denied, mercenary women are necessary members: they pluck down the pride of the flesh, yet are not proud themselves , for they will be as familiar with the men as with the Master: they do as many good deeds as some Fryers that puts one to penance for his sins, they put twenty to pains: he out of charity sends one to the Hospital once a year, they send twenty to the Surgeons once a month. Say he bids men repent, they make them repent, yet for all this some will call them damned Punks: well, if they be damned, they will not be damned gratis like your young country Gentlemen, nor in hugger mugger like your Citizen's wife with her Prentice. They can practise without an overseer: they scorn to have a Suburban Bawd lend them a Taffeta gown, and they (like your common Players) let men come in for two pence a piece, and yet themselves to have but the tenth penny, like the tenth Pig, yet faith the trade is a good trade: They forswear not themselves , in commendation of their wares, as your common Tradesmen do , swearing they cannot afford it at the price. They are no proverb breakers: beware the buyer say they, you shall have enough for your money, if half will not serve your turn take the whole, measure by your own yard, you shall have Winchester measure, I was somewhat bold with one of their Ladyships this morning, and asked her why women went to the generating sport all the year, since beasts themselves went to it but once? And she answered me, because they were women, and had reason to know what was good for themselves , and so had not beasts: but soft, here comes Signior Petoune.

sp.speaker: Sp Pet.
sp.p: O Fleire, how dost Fleire?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: O Signior, you may snuff out your smoke here Signior, and save your oath too, here are no Cuckold makers.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.p: What are they Fleire?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Women Signior, women: I heard what a rash Gentleman you are to forswear your Mistress company in the very heat of your affection.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Hang her, hang her, she is a very crickee, she&Htp; hath written for me three or four times, but I will see her damned ere I will come to her, would take any Tobacco Fleire?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: No, not I; I will not make my nose a red Herring, I will not hang him in the smoke.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Thou art a good Courtier Fleire, thou hast got a suit already.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Nay, I have two or three Offices too.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Prithee what are they?

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: Why I am Yeoman at the Iurden, Gentleman at the smock and Squire of entertainment: for when your Gallants approach, I take their income , for if I stay till their out come, the devil a bit of any silver sir can I get: for your new made Gallants lay all on the back and spend all at the belly.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: How do thy two Ladies live Fleire?

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: Like two musk-cats in a Coop.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Why? I hear say they live gallantly.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Phew, they? why they keep a little court.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: And what art thou? a Sumner?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: A Sumner, why?

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Because thou art one of them ; hark in thine ear.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: Well said Calf, hast been a sucking all this while for that jest? No, I have an honourable place, I am one of their leaders, for their shoes are so hie, and their heels so short if they should not be led, they would play domestic tricks abroad, and show all.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Thou their leader! why do they mean to go to the wars?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: I think so, for I am sure here were a couple of gentlemen last night that scoured their pieces.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: I think Fleir thy Ladies are not we rich.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: How can they? they spend when others get.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Dost hear Fleir? would prefer me to their service?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: What! shall we embrace? shall we have red-nosed Corporals here: what you rogue? will you turn Sumner? away you whale-nosed rogue away, go, snuffle, snuffle in the Ocean, away you slave.

sp.speaker: Pet,
sp.p: Is thy name Fleir? thou art a flattering, fleering, cogging knave.

body.stage: Exit. Enter two Ladies, one singing:

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: His man's red hose, were the colour of his nose,
and his breech was made of blue,
And he in shape, but a Frenchman's Ape,
And so sweet sir adieu.
"Holla, holla ye pampered Jades of Asia,
"And can you draw but twenty miles a day?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Give me a bow, I will hit the Sun.

sp.speaker: Fel,
sp.p: Why it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: No more canst thou hit true felicity.

sp.speaker: Fel,
sp.p: O I am in an excellent humour, now I could laugh, dance, leap, or do any light tricks that belongs to a light wench.

sp.speaker: Flo;
sp.p: But look who is here?

sp.speaker: Fel,
sp.p: O seignior Fleir, how dost, how dost man? we may be merry before thee, thou wilt be secret, wilt not?

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: As your Midwife, or Barber Surgeon Madam;

sp.speaker: Fel:
sp.p: How likest the City Fleir, ha, how likest it?

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: Faith well Madam, were not your Citizens, such heavy head fellows:

sp.speaker: Fel,
sp.p: That is a sign they are no drunkards.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Indeed Madam, drink lightens the head, the heart, the heels, the pot, the purse, but it makes heavy chamberpots, full bowels, and foul rooms enough.

sp.speaker: Fel:
sp.p: How dost like the Gentlemen of this Country?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: I can compare your Gentleman, and your Merchant, to nothing so fitly as your Flea and your Louse: I had rather trust your louse with a hundred pound, than your Flea with forty; for your Louse, like the Merchant, stands to it , you shall know where to find him, but your Flea, like the Gentleman, if you take him not at first sight, he slips from you.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: Methinks they have a strange fashion here , they take money with their wives, and give money to their wenches.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: And good reason too (Madam) would you have a man be troubled with a wife, as long as he lives for nothing? He gives money to his wench, to be as soon rid of her as he has done with her.

sp.speaker: Fel:
sp.p: What is the reason Fleir, the Citizens' wives wear all Corks in their shoes?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: O Madam, to keep the custom of the City, only to be light heeled. The City is like a Comedy, both in parts and in apparel, and your Gallants are the Actors: for he&Htp; that yesterday played the Gentleman, now plays the Beggar; she&Htp; that played the Waiting woman, now plays the Quean; he&Htp; that played the married-man, now plays the Cuckold; and she&Htp; that played the Lady, now plays the Painter. Then for their apparel, they have change too: for she&Htp; that wore the Petticoat, now wears the Breech; he&Htp; that wore the Coxcomb, now wears the feather; the Gentleman that wore the long Sword, now wears the short Hanger; and he&Htp; that could scarce get Velvet for his Cape, has now lined his Cloak throughout with it.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: But how dost like the Court Fleir?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p:
Well enough , if they did not catch their meat so; it comes no sooner from Table, but the one fellow has a fat Duck by the rump, the other a slippery Eel by the tail, and an old Courtier that best knew the tricks on it , was
mumbling of a Cony in a corner alone by himself .

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: What good cheer didst see there?

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Faith there was much good meat, but methought your fair Lady was your only dish.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Aye , but that is a costly dish, and will ask rich saucing.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Faith for mine own part when I had a stomach, I should like it best in it own naked kind, without any sauce at all.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What is the news now at Court Fleir?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Faith they say your Ladies cannot endure the old fashion Spur, they say it hangs to a man's heel like a Wheelbarrow, but they love the fine little Scots Spur, it makes the Court Jennet curvet, curvet gallantly.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: I prithee Fleir, how goes the report of us two abroad?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: If I should tell you, I fear your Ladyships would be angry.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No not a whit.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: But alas they are your common people, they are like your Slippers, they are always gaping, their mouths are never shut.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: But what say they of us ?

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Alas Madam, their tongues are like your dry leather shoes, always creaking:

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: But I prithee tell us , what do they say of us ?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: I shall offend your Ladyships.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: I tell thee no.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: But alas Madam, I do not believe them, because I know the conditions of the slaves; why I will tell you, their tongues are like the Jack of a Clock, still in labour.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I think thou art mad, I prithee tell us what they say.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I would be loath to displease you.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: I tell thee thou shalt not.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Faith they say your Ladyships are a couple of stately Courtesans.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Faith that was not much amiss, said they no worse?

sp.speaker: Flei,
sp.p: You will not be angry with me.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: No at my word.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: By my troth they said stately whores.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: What pagan rogues be these? were they but roasted Larks for my sake, I would crush them bones and all.

sp.speaker: Fel,
sp.p: Why? are you so angry sister? you know they speak truth.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: Why are we whores?

sp.speaker: Fel,
sp.p: What are we else?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why we are Courtesans.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: And what difference pray ye ?

sp.speaker: Flei.
sp.p: O great great madam, your whore is for every rascal but your Courtesan is for your Courtier.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: He has given you a difference now.

sp.speaker: Flei,
sp.p: And indeed Madam I said so, for in truth I was very angry with them , but they said you were for every serving man too.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: Did they say so?

sp.speaker: Flei,
sp.p: Yes indeed Madam, I hope I have touched you now.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: I will hold my life this slave the Serving-man, that was with me this morning, has bragged of my kindness to him.

sp.speaker: Flei,
sp.p: Nay, that is likely, never trust a fellow that will flatter, fleire, and fawn for four nobles a year.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: Well, I will never have Serving-man touch any linen of mine again .

sp.speaker: Flei,
sp.p: Yes Madam, he may touch it when it is at the Laundresses.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: Aye , at my Laundresses, or else not: but what a rascal is this? by this light, I will never suffer serving-man come near me again .

sp.speaker: Flei,
sp.p: Yes Madam, to deliver you a letter or so.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: By this hand, not unless the Rogue kiss his hand first.

sp.speaker: Flei,
sp.p:
O Madam! why? since blue coats were left oft, the kissing of the hand is the servingman's badge, you shall know him by it : but Madam, I speak something boldly of you now and then, when I am out of your hearing, to hear
what the world will say of you, for you know that is the way to pump filthy words out of their mouths, if there be any in them.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: And do so still, we allow thee to say anything , for thereby we shall know our friends from our foes.

sp.speaker: Flei,
sp.p: I assure your Ladyships, I love you, and am sorry for you from my soul, although you know it not.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: We doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Come sister will you in?

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: I prithee Fleire inform us how the tide of opinion runs on us, lest we be drowned in the slanderous imaginations of the world.

sp.speaker: Flei,
sp.p: I shall be very vigilant of your reputations.

sp.speaker: Amb,
sp.p: Be so.

sp.speaker: Flei,
sp.p: Who comes here in Gods-name? O, my gallant ruffles it out in silk, where have you been all this while?

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: Faith at Court Fleire, when wert thou there?

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Faith but yesterday, where I saw a Farmers Son sit newly made a courtier, that sat in the presence at cards, as familiar as if the chair of state had been made of a piece of his fathers Barn-door: O it is a shame: I would have state be state in earnest and in game, I like your Courtier for nothing but often saying his prayers.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: What, I think thou seldom sayst thy prayers, since thou hast almost forgot thy Pater-noster.

sp.speaker: Flei,
sp.p: Faith I pray once a week, dost thou pray oftener?

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: I did pray oftener when I was an Englishman, but I have not prayed often, I must confess since I was a Britain: but dost hear Fleire? canst tell me if an Englishman were in debt, whether a Britain must pay it or no?

sp.speaker: Flei,
sp.p: No, questionless no.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: I am glad of that, I hope some honest statute will come shortly, and wipe out all my scores.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: But what is the news now abroad Master Ruffell?

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: Why they say the Courtiers shall make the Citizens no more Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Excellent news i'faith, excellent news, then the Court will grow rich.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: Rich? Why man why?

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Why then your Courtier will not bestow his money in buying the Merchants idle commodities to lie with his wife.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: Fleire I did but to try thee, the tide of the flood is turned man.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Then let them sweat for it .

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: If they strive against the stream.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: No, but I mean the Citizens must cuckold the courtiers

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Excellent news i'faith, excellent news, then the court will grow rich.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: What, like your weaver's shuttle? make cloth forward and backward, but how I prithee? but hark you Fleire, are you capable of a secret?

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: As your common Cockatrice, that receives the secrets of every man.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Then I must entreat, I may trust thee.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: That is because I am no Taylor, for if I were, thou wouldst entreat me to trust thee.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: Sirrah, they say your Ladies are a couple of common Punks, I hope I may trust you with a secret?

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Sir, sir, do ye hear, do ye think they are no worse?

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: Worse! why can they be worse?

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: I tell you he that takes up his private Punk's linen, were better take up any commodity about the Town: if it were a commodity of Mousetraps, he should not lose much by the bargain.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: But hark you Fleire hark you, it is supposed I can tell you they are a couple of private Punks.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Nay, then there is some hope they will prove honest women.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Yea, how Fleire how?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p:
Why your private punk would leave being a punk, rather than be private to one man for nothing, and then if all men were like thee, they would be honest, for thou hast
nothing to give them .

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: What a cogging fleering Rogue is this, nothing will anger him: but do ye hear Fleire; art thou a procurer, or a knave? For one of them I am sure thou art.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: A procurer! what is that?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: One that procures means for procreation, vulgarly called a Pander.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: By this light now, were I a notable Rogue, should I deny my profession, why, I am a procurer sir.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: Nay, then thou art a Knave too that is certain, for there is such a sympathy between a Procurer and a knave, as there is betwixt an Alchemist and a Beggar.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: But look you sir, pray ye will you tell me one thing now.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Are you a Whoremaster or a Thief, for one of them I am sure you are.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: By this light now he comes near me too, why I am a whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Nay, then you are a thief too, that is certain, for your whoremaster always filcheth for victuals, for you know flesh is man's food, marry sir you cannot be hanged for it, it is but petty larceny at most, but you may chance be whipped for it and burned too, but not in the hand Signior, not in the hand.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Save ye Gentles.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Then we are enemies to the Jews.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: O my good preferer, how does your worship, you are a stranger here .

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Faith I have been with two Gentlewomen, in whose company thou first sawest us , and there the Knight, Sir Iohn Haue-little is so in love with the younger, as he knows not whether he should rejoice, she&Htp; had so much beauty: or lament, because he is like to enjoy none of it .

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: By my troth I took him for a Conjurer, when I first saw him, he talked so much of his soul and the Devil.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Why he sold his soul to the Devil man, for the velvet that lines his cloak.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: And when will he give the Devil his dew?

sp.speaker: Sp,
sp.p: Nay, he deals with him, as he does with his Tailor, goes upon trust and means to pay them both at the latter day.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: But does not the Gentlemen jest at him?

sp.speaker: Sp,
sp.p: Yes, one of them asked if he were a celestial or a terrestrial Knight, and he very ignorantly asked what Knights they were? your terrestrial Knight quoth she, is of a gross element, and lives upon lands of his own , but your celestial Knight, he&Htp; lives by the Heir, that is, by his elder Brother. He it was, was Knighted, when so few scaped the sword, and he it is that now lives by the sword.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: And what said the Knight, what said he?

sp.speaker: Sp,
sp.p: Faith as some Courtiers do , laugh at that he did not understand, and swore an oath or two of the new fashion, as, by my conscience Lady you have a very good spirit, and so after two or three Court complements, beseeched the Ladies retain him still in their good graces, kissed his hand and went his way.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Faith methinks your English Ladies were very gallant Creatures, had they not one fault.

sp.speaker: Sp,
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: I have heard say, they will rise sooner, and go with more devotion to see an extraordinary execution, than to hear a Sermon.

sp.speaker: Sp,
sp.p: O seignior, condemn not all for some, indeed I must confess there have been Ladies at executions.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Aye , and they sat bare faced too, for fear the little fleet holes of their masks should not give their eyes room enough for such a prospect: one Lady thrust her head so far out at a window, with greedy desire to see all, that the whole body was like to follow, making a forked tree with her head down , had not her Gentleman Usher, contrary to the nature of his office, catched hold of her behind.

sp.speaker: Sp,
sp.p: A forked tree; why what tree dost thou think she&Htp; would have made?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: O sir, a Medlar-tree a Medlar-tree.

sp.speaker: Sp,
sp.p: But Fleire, how does the Gentleman Usher live with thy Ladies?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p:
Faith sir in the nature of a Monkey, that flatters and
fawns, and shakes his tail in his Mistress lap: but i'faith Gallants, hether are you two bound now?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: We are even ready for your two Ladies Seignior;

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Faith and you shall find my two Ladies as ready for you two: Come, come, I will put you in the way of all flesh, I will send you to Graues-ende, I will see you in the Tilt-boat, When you are there, ship yourselves : in, in, in.

body.stage: Ex. Spe. & Ruf. Enter Piso and Knight.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: How is it Fleir?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: O my Lord, you are a welcome man.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Save you O seignior.

sp.speaker: Fleir:
sp.p: O my gracious knight, and whither are you two bound now?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Faith even to your two Ladies seignior,

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Yea? and will you to the South-ward i'faith? will you to the confines of Italy my Gallants? take heed how ye go Northwards, it is a dangerous Coast, jest not with it in Winter, therefore go Southwards my Gallants, South-wards ho: I have shipped two Gallants in a storm, I fear they have spent their main Masts by this time, and are coming home again : but if you will Southwards, my hearts of gold, I will ship you in pomp, I will send ye under the very line, where the sun is at hottest.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: But come, shall we go see thy Ladies, Fleir?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, Aye , Come: but my good Lord you will be a welcome man, for I have heard her often swear, that had she such a Husband, a man so richly decked in virtuous ornaments, she&Htp; would forsake this life, herself , nay, her very being, to be yours; O my good Lord, she&Htp; loves you dearly.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Phew, but I cannot requite it,

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Why my good Lord?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: she is a common thing.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: But say she may turn my Lord.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: She has been so much worn, she is not worth the turning now.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: O my Lord, penitence doth purge a spotted soul, and better leave sin late than not at all: and I do know my Lord, that for your love from her immodest life she will turn.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Aye, Aye , I doubt not but she will turn: but it will be like a Buzzard Hawk that turns her tail to her game.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Fleir, is the gentleman usher that I preferred to your Ladies in any favour with them?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Great, great: he kisses his hand with an excellent grace, and a will leer and fleire upon them, he is partly their Physician, he makes them Suppositories, and gives them Glisters.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: And how lives he with them .

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Faith like Thisbe in the play, he has almost killed himself with the scabbard: but hark you Knight, you will be a welcome man to my younger Lady, I protest she&Htp; thinkes worthily of you.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Seignior, I must confess, I am beholding to your Lady; and to tell you truly, I have much affected her since I first saw her.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Upon my word sir, to my knowledge she is an honest Gentlewoman, yet the world may chance speak ill of her. Why I have heard some say Penelope was a Punk, having no reason to suspect her, but because she&Htp; set up late a-nights, when it was but to undo that which she&Htp; did by day. I have heard some say Hercules was a coward because he&Htp; did not fight at single Rapier like a gallant, but with a Club.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Nay, I have no reason to think the worse of her for the report of the world; for the world seignior perchance speaks ill of you, or me.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p:
Why, ye are in the right, I have heard some say, you were a very needy Knight, and that you had but one shirt to your back when you came first to this town; Nay more, when your Lackey carried it to the Laundress, it was found to be a woman's smock, that you had borrowed: but what? should my Lady, or I
believe this now ?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I hope she&Htp; doth not,

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: Come Fleir shall we see thy Ladies?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Aye, aye , ho, who is within there?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: What would you have master Fleir?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Prithee show these Gentlemen up into the great Chamber, and give my Ladies notice of their being here, have a little business my Lords, he will conduct ye , ye shall find a couple of your acquaintance there.

Could I but work Lord Piso, and my eldest daughter, to make them both affect and love each other, that marriage might unite their hearts together: O then there were assured hope we might redeem our honours lost, and regain our right in Florence. And for this Knight though he&Htp; be poor, yet would he&Htp; married were unto Felitia
sp.l: For of a loving husbands awful eye,
Sets right the woman's steps that went awry.
Heaven I know has grace enough in store,
To make most chaste, a most lascivious whore.
sp.stage: Enter the two wenches in boyes apparell.
sp.p: How now? Who have we here? a couple of footmen?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: You see sir, we are not on horseback.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: How now my little fireworks of wit? what? flashes and flames? tell me true, were you never Ushers to some great man's Coach-mares? did you never run bare before them?

sp.speaker: Nan,
sp.p: Never we sir:

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Sir we want a service, and are going to get a Master.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p:
Come, come I will prefer you both, thou shalt serve a Countryman of mine, he is going to travel: shalt
go with him, and thou shalt serve one of my Ladies.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: We would willingly serve two ne'er friends, because we are brothers, and indeed two twins, and therefore are loath to be parted.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: Two twins? that is all one, come, come, you shall serve them .

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You shall pardon us sir.

body.stage: Enter Flor, Sparke, Felee: Ruffell, Piso, Knight and Fromaga.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I hope you will not condemn me for my love.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: I have no reason Lady.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: I offered you unasked.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: That with a number oft hath bought.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: Partly they have , and partly not, for I would have you know, my function seldom sells affection: what though I have evil lived? repentant tears can wash away my sin, which I will poor forth like drops of winter rain, and now henceforth, ever I will this life abhor, and to the earth my knees I will daily bow, to get mercy from heaven, love from you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: O the devil take impudency she courts him.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Madam, the love that I may give you, fully do enjoy, but I have sworn with other love than as a Brother doth a sister never to love any.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: O sir, my fortunes are not fellows with my birth, they make me stoop to base dejected courses, but would you love me, I would as swift as thought fly this life, and leave lusts foulest sin, for fleshly beasts to sleep and wallow in.

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: Shame to thy sex, no more.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Lady, in all the honest offices that friendship may command, command me still, but yet I have not seen the face to which I owe so much of love, as may justly arrest my affections, and when I do, I will pay so due a debt without imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Pis:
sp.p:
Methinks yond Lady grows fairer much than
she was wont, methinks her feature mends, and her comely gesture, much hath drawn my heart to love her, O but she is a whore.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Gentlemen do you lack a Boy?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: No,

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: O God, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: Sir do ye want a Servant?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: O Lord what shall I do ?

sp.speaker: Pis:
sp.p: What canst do ?

sp.speaker: Na:
sp.p: Anything that a Boy should do .

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Would dwell with me?

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: It is partly as you will use me.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: I will use thee well.

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Pis:
sp.p: Tell me, are you both content to dwell with us two?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: As please you two.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Then thou shalt live with me.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: And thou with me.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Come Gentlemen will you be going?

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: We attend you sir.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Ladies our occasions calls us hence, and I am sorry we must leave you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Gentlemen you all both have , and ever shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Pis:
sp.p: Lady I will leave you much affection more than I thought to lend you, but I deal on use, and have much interest.

sp.speaker: Flei.
sp.p: Caught I hope: hold hook and line, he is fast by heaven.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My Lord, what you lend me, with much interest shall be repaid.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Fare you well; refused.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Contemned.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: Disdained.

sp.speaker: Fel:
sp.p: Abused.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: He dies.

sp.speaker: Fel,
sp.p: He shall not live.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Disdain the Daughter of such a Signior.

sp.speaker: Fel,
sp.p: Condemn a Lady born? sister we are wronged.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: But if you will consent I have a project laid, that in requital both of them shall die.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You make my soul sweet harmony, come let us about it then.

body.stage: Actus Tertius Scena prima. Enter the Ladies each with a Letter, and Fleire aside.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Are we in private?

sp.speaker: Fel,
sp.p: We are?

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.p: Pray Sister what moving lines of love has your Knight touched your affection with?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Faith his style is plain, only a little court-like silken phrase it has, but I hope your lord hath sent rich words like jewels, for your ears against your nuptial day.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Faith a woes with lines that might persuade another thought, not me , which I will lend your eyes, upon the like received courtesy from you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What have we here ?

Lady I know the nobleness of your disposition defends you from the least Sparke of baseness, wherefore I invocate every particular virtue of yours to be mediators to your best judgment for my better estimation in your love, my affection is zealous, my intent honourable, my desire marriage: thus desiring your resolved answers, I rest. Ever at your disposure: Jack haue-little Knight.
Upon my life some friend did pen it for the fool.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Let me see what is this?

You the understanding spirit of a woman, let the splendour of your Beauty, with some heat of your affection shine upon the
creature that adores ye , and with the heavenly comfort of your love, melt and thaw despair from my dying heart which if it live, it lives to love, it aye if it dies in love, but howsoever, it is yours, it was made for you, lives by you, and diet without you. Yours in the most affectionate degree of affection. Don Piso De Florence.
Sister upon my life this is son and heir to Duke Piso that now is.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: O would he&Htp; were! but whosoever he be, he must be made a match to give fire to the hell black powder of our revenge, yet your love: the wise Knight and he, are two in one, there are no such friends as they.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Then let them march both hand in hand in one way.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: Then shall be thus: these two being earnest suitors for our loves, we will grant upon condition, that suddenly they murther Sparke and Ruffell, but first to take the Sacrament if ever it be known as known it will be, to keep our names unspotted in the action; this being done,

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Let them challenge us, we , and our loves are won, but say they should reveal us .

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: O none will break a Sacrament to heap up perjury on other sins, when death and hell stands gaping for their souls.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: But say they rail on us .

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: If they do, it is known, we loved Sparke, and Ruffel, and men will think they killed them for our loves, since they lived in our favour these in disgrace.

sp.speaker: Fel,
sp.p: I like it well, come let us hasten it, For this is even as true as ever was text, Plots are but dreams until they take effects.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: O God, I think the path to hell that women tread is brother than the way men go: how they walk by couples to the Devil?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: O that I should love a whore, a very common Cockatrice, my thoughts are drowned in a gulf of sin, she is a very Cannibal, which doth devour man's flesh, and a Horse-leach that sucks out men's best blood's perfection: a very prisoners box, that is ope for every man's benevolence: and I am Heir unto a Duke, yet love her: doth any man here love a whore? Aye , who? Aye, Aye, Aye, it is I, an arrant punk and common hired Hackney, and yet I love her; I adore her, I dote on her, I worship her, O would some goodman would cut my throat, and put me out of pain --- of pain, O that nature would not make an honest woman!

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: She did, she did my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: Art there? speak, who was it ?

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Eve, Eve my Lord, she was honest.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: Art sure of it ?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Aye sure my Lord, for there was no man to tempt her but her husband.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: I thought it was some such country Gentlewoman, O Fleire, Fleire I love a whore.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Why my Lord, were you never a Soldier?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Yes, yes,

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Why then it is your profession, you need not be ashamed of your trade.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: But Fleire would help me, would help me man?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Aye, Aye , who is it ?

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: Thy Lady, thy elder Lady.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: O my Lord, love her? why she is a whore.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: Aye Fleire, but she may turn.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: But she&Htp; is so much worn my Lord, she is not worth turning now.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: do not vex me, do not torment me: do not torture me upon the rack of jests, I tell thee if she&Htp; please, she may turn.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: Aye my Lord, tail to her game, like a buzzard hawk, or so:

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p:
Yet again , now the Devil take thy body, and damnation light upon thy soul, destruction on thy bones,
confusion in thy marrow, dost scorn me, mock me, vex me, torment me ? dost? dost? I will hang myself , nay, I will damn myself rather than love thy Lady, and be abused by thee: I will, I will.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: O Fleir how does thy Lady?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I delivered your letter sir, and she thanks you for it :

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: And how does she? ha, how does she?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Faith not well, she has taken physic, and your gentleman usher there ministers to her: she very great, and she says she feels much stirring in her belly.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Sure then Fleir she has eaten too much raw fruit.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Upon my life then, they be plums, and the stones make her swell.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Sure then it is so, I should send her something to comfort her now being sick: what dost think were best Fleir?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Send her an Oaten cake, it is a good Northern token: sir Raph Shave sent his Mistress one, but I think he meant to ride a journey on her, and thought Oats would make her travel well.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: No, Oates is too great a binder after her Physic, I care not if I go and visit her, and carry her a Woodcock.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: You will go alone sir.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Aye, Aye mean so, but how should I carry him Fleir?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Under your Cloak sir, under your Cloak.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Mas, and thou sayst true, I will go buy one straight, and yet now I remember me, it is no great matter if I defer it till she be well, it shall be so Fleir, I will.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: O ye are of a French humour sir, as inconstant as impatient: I think you have scarce the patience to tell the clock when it strikes.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Tush, I keep a boy for such uses.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: For nothing else?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Yes, to wear a guarded Cloak.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Not till you be richly married.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: No, not till I be richly married: he&Htp; should wear one now, if my money were come out of the Country.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I wonder you would be knighted sir, since your money is so long a-coming, that you cannot maintain your knighthood gallantly.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Faith I was knighted to get me a good wife Fleir.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Get you a good wife? Why look you sir, speak but the Golden tongue very perfectly, marry you must speak it well, and call some great Lord cousin: it will get you a better wife than three hundred pound jointer. You may report you have Coal-pits too,, it is a warm commodity I can tell you: they may be sent about by water; if they never come, as your money doth not, you may curse the winds, or complain of Shipwreck: and then though it be a lie it is drowned.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Aye , but say it should be proved afterwards it was not true.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: True? Gods my life, she is a wise woman that will go as far as new Castle to search the depth of a Cole-pit for your truth.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I would be loath to leave my truth so far hence.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: But I am sure he will bring his honesty no nearer hither; but that comes about by water too as his money does.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: But Fleir is not thy Lady a virtuous Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: O yes sir, I often find her in deep contemplation.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Of what I prithee?

sp.speaker: Flr.
sp.p: Of Aratines pictures.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Aye, Aye warrant her, O she can endure no bawdry, she&Htp; spits when she hears one speak of it .

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: That is because her mouth waters at it.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: She is wondrous musical too.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Very true, she every day sings Iohn for the King, and at up tails all, she is perfect.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Be these good tunes Fleir?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Excellent, excellent sir, far better than your Scottish Jigs.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Yet many of our Ladies delight much in the Scottish Music.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Aye , with their Instruments.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Thou hast a good wit Fleir: if I were a great man thou shouldst be my Secretary.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: And I hope I should discharge the place sufficiently: for I have learning enough to take a bribe, and wit enough to be proud: but whither are you going now sir?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Faith I am going to thy Ladies Fleir.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: You will not speak with them now; for my Ladies will speak with none but Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Why sir, I hope I am a Knight, and Knights are before Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: What Knights before Gentlemen, say ye?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Faith Aye .

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: That is strange, they were wont to be Gentlemen fore they were knighted: but for this news I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Do , and as occasion serves I will prefer thee.

body.stage:
Exeunt.
Enter Piso, and Nan as his Boy.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: Why should I love her? because she is fair, because she is fair; because she is a whore: for if she were not fair, she would not be a whore; and if she were not fair, I should not love her: Ergo, if she&Htp; were not a whore I should not love her: well concluded wit, well concluded wit; there is no man breathing could love her but I, she is a whore, yet her beauty haunts me like a Ghost, I cannot sleep for it , her remembrance rides me like the Mare a nights, I cannot rest for it , what shall I do ? I shall burst boy.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: Will thy tongue be secret?

sp.speaker: Nan,
sp.p: As the clapper of a Mill, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Is not that always going?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Aye my Lord, but I hope it says nothing.

sp.speaker: Piso,
sp.p: O thou hast wit I see I am in love boy, I am, I am.

sp.speaker: Nan
sp.p: With whom my Lord?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: With a very Wagtail an arrant woman, a very Peace whose pride is maintained by her tail.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Then it is maintained by the worthiest part of her body

sp.speaker: Pis:
sp.p: Come, your wit boy, your proof.

sp.speaker: Nan,
sp.p: If a hundred men in a company, meet doth not the worthiest man amongst them, first take his place, and sit down ?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: I grant it.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And I am sure my Lord, where ever the body comes the tail first takes his place, and sits down , and therefore I hope it is the worthiest part of the body.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: O that I had the reason of a Sailor to know her like a rock, that I might sail from her and avoid her: or as a virtuous man knows sin, to loath and leave it. And yet she is wondrous fair, I would she were as honest: kind usage may reclaim her from her sin, and make her stoop unto her Husbands will, as doth a well-manned Hawk unto the lure.

sp.speaker: Na:
sp.p: O Aye, she&Htp; has been manned already, she knows the lure and will come to any call.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: O but her beauty may excuse the folly of her youth, it is want of maintenance hath overthrown her, want and pride are two notorious bawds: want makes the noblest creature sell her soul for gold, and pride doth make the gallants stoop to lust.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: And often sells pure honesty, to clad her tail in glittering bravery.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: If it well done, let every member wear that which it won: why should the head study to maintain the foot?

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Or the foot trot to maintain the head?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Why should not every member like a mechanic man in a common-wealth, labour in his own trade to maintain itself ? then since every thing must live, I will no more condemn beauty for being clad in luxury, but henceforth I will love her, and let my passion smoothly swim along the stream of love's affection: henceforth I will no more with foul and hated thoughts, abuse so rare a creature, whose behaviour and discourse, enchants the ears of men, and drives the world into a wonder --- ay me!

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p:
Faith my Lord you will never win a woman by sighing,
crossing your arms, and crying aye me ! the only way to win them is to care little for them : when they are sad do ye sing: when they sing and are merry, then take your time and put them to it : if they will, so: if not, let them snick up , if you will walk in my Lord, I will show ye many principles I learned of my Mother, they may do your lordship good.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Go go, I will: but O unhappy fate, When youth and weakness must support our state.

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter Fleire one way, Sparke, Ruffell and Petoune another way.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: How now Fleire?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Save you Fleire.

sp.speaker: Flei,
sp.p: Save ye Gallants: O Signior Petoune, shall you and I be friends again?

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Why are ye enemies?

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: No great enemies, a quarrel rose between us .

sp.speaker: Pet,
sp.p: I do not like such quarrels, he struck me sir, and I protest and swear to you sir by this Trinidado, had I not taken the box on my cheek, he had broke my Pipe.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Why didst not strike him again ?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: O no, his Father is a Justice.

sp.speaker: Flei,
sp.p: Nay if the Father be of the peace, I see no reason the Son should fight.

sp.speaker: Ruff
sp.p: What, a Coward Signior? fie, a coward?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: A Coward? why that is his only virtue, for a Coward abuseth no man, but he makes him satisfaction: for if he wrong all men, he gives all men leave to beat him, he is like a whetstone, he sets an edge on another, and yet he will not cut himself .

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Come, come, we must needs have you friends, and thou wouldst do him some good offices.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Who? I? with all my heart, but what is it sir? what is it ?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Thou shalt commend his love to Madam Fromaga.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: His love to her? what Signior, in love with my Lady's Ancient?

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Why her Ancient?

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p:
Because she&Htp; carries her colours for her, but it is in a
box: but signior you shall have a good match of it , though she be not rich, yet she is an ancient woman and is able to get her living, by midwifery, and I can tell ye it is not the worst trade going, considering how young and old, and all do their good wills to set them a work, and it is a good hearing, better they get than the Lawyers, for your midwives live by the agreement between party and party, and the falling in of lovers, but the Lawyers live by the falling out of friends.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: I pray sir what may she be worth?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Worth? let me see, she&Htp; hath three yellow periwigs of her own: she hath a Pan with a short silver handle about the length of a Barber's syringe: she has a Looking-glass too, but that has played the prodigal Citizen with liar, it is broken, and much other goods of the same nature.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: But come Signior, how will you woe her?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I will tell her she is so wise, that neither age nor time could cousin her of beauty.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: And by my faith that will do well.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I will tell her that I love her most for the whiteness of her skin.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: But you may not say the sweetness of her breath, for that stinks.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I will praise the smallness of her fingers.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: But I assure you, you may better praise the length of her nails.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I am afraid that being old she&Htp; has a dry hand.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: That is certain, but she has a very moist nose, you may praise her for that: but my Gallants why are ye such strangers at our little Court?

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Because thy Ladies live like the Beadles of Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: How is that sir?

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: By the sins of the people.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: They say the Lord Piso, hath been a good Client to thy elder Lady of late.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p:
The more fool he ? why your good Client is but
like your study gown, sits in the cold himself , to keep the Lawyer warm.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: And what fees hast thou out of their trade?

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Faith my fees are like a puny Clerk's, a penny a sheet

sp.speaker: Sp,
sp.p: How a penny a sheet?

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Why, if any lie with them a whole night, I make the bed in the morning, and for that I have two pence, and that is a penny a sheet.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: What Gallants use to come to your house?

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: All sorts, all nations, and all trades: there is first Master Gallant your Britain, Master Metheglins your Welshman, Monsieur Mustroome the Frenchman: Signior Fumada the Spaniard, Master Oscabath the Irishman: and Master Shamrough his Lackey, O and Master Slopdragon the Dutchman. Then for your Trades-men, there comes first Master Saluberrimum the Physician, Master Smooth the Silk-man, Master Thimble the Taylor, Master Blade the Cutler, and Master Rowel the Spurrier: but Master Match the Gunner of Tower-hill comes often; he has taught my Ladies to make fireworks, they can deal in Chambers already, as well as all the Gunners that make them fly off with a train at Lambeth, when the Mayor and Aldermen land at Westminster: but come Signior, you have Tobacco, and I will give you a Cup of Mulled sack and we will even go drink a health to our Mistresses.

body.stage:
Actus Quartus.
Enter the two Ladies Piso and Knight, and Fromaga one way: Sparke, Ruffell, Petoune and Fleire another way.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: Health to our best esteemed friends, Master Spark and Master Ruffell.

sp.speaker: Fel:
sp.p: Our, good wishes ever wait upon our best beloved friends Master Ruffell, and Master Sparke.

sp.speaker: Ambo:
sp.p: We both are much indebted to your Ladyships.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Look ye signior, that is she: whose love means to assault your brains, since you have blown up your own sconce with Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
As I am truly generous, she is modest.
Fair Mistress, you are so wise, that neither time nor age could ever cozen you of beauty, and I swear even by the Alps' high heaven-touching tops, the travellers narrow passage, and by the towering head of high mount Chiego, the Sea-mas southward mark: by these the witnesses unto my travel, I do vow that you are passing fair.

sp.speaker: From:
sp.p: If I be not fair sir, I must be foul.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: A Foul Lady? what bird might that be?

sp.speaker: Fro:
sp.p: A foul Lady? ye are a saucy Jack to call me so, that you are.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: O be not angry, for I protest I cannot but commend the whiteness of your skin.

sp.speaker: From:
sp.p: Marry muff, I think he be a Tanner, and means to buy me for my skin.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: Gods me, she is angry, what shall I do now Signior?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: To her again man, do not leave her, the Moon is now upon change, she will turn.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: I pray you Lady know me by the title of some kindness.

sp.speaker: From.
sp.p: Kindness; faith sir you are mistaken in me , you must seek your flirts some other where, and I pray ye come not to make a fool of me: alas man though I am a waiting-woman, do not think I spend my time in nothing but tempering of colours, working of drawn-work, warming of Smocks, and pinning in of ruffs, faith yes.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: If you come to her Signior you must come to her as country Gentlewomen do into the fashion, that is: in the tail and latter end of it .

sp.speaker: From,
sp.p:
Faith Aye, if ye come to begin your knavery on me, I will take you down: I am none of your young simpering waiting-women, that are ashamed to be counted proud, and therefore suffer every Serving-man to use them at their
pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Now on my conscience Mistress, my love is honest, and I desire marriage.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Indeed if you mean marriage, I am content to bear the more with you: but I pray ye sir, when shall we be married? by my troth I ask you, because I have been so often deceived, I warrant you I have been promised and dealt upon promises in the way of marriage above an hundred times.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: At our next meeting we will set down a day for the effecting of it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Gentlemen, we have some small discourse which a little requires secrecy, therefore if it please ye to walk in, and make use of our better rooms, we will not long be absent from you.

sp.speaker: Sp. & Ruf
sp.p: With all our hearts.

body.stage: Exeunt. Manent two Ladies the Lord and Knight: Felicia, and the two Wenches disguised, hide themselues.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Worthy Lord, do not think immodesty in me though contrary to the bashful habit of my sex, I am enforced by love's almighty power, to reveal the secretes of my heart. Your Letters have so much prevailed with me , that in a word I must confess I love you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Worthy Knight, I would my words had but the power to work in you, that which your lines have done in me, then should the happy consolation of my life dwell ever in your love's embracements.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Assure ye Lady, your gift of love to me shall be deserved, though nothing but my lives dear breath requite its.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: And I will rather die a shameful death, than live a hateful life, which I must do unless I find a means that may deserve your love.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
Now your tongue goes like a well tuned Instrument, and makes my heart within my bosom dance with joy to hear such large requital of my love: but durst you to maintain this your affection, although it
were with some danger of your life?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Durst I? I vow, even by my soul's eternity, I durst.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: Alas, if you knew all, it is your own good, not mine: and yet I lie, it is my good too, since my life depends upon your safety.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: What is it dear Lady? although it be the death of man, if it be pleasing unto you I will do it .

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: O let me embrace so dear a spirit in so dear a bosom: and since you have bound yourself by promise, I will be plain, there are two that hate you two, because we love you, and often have persuaded us by gifts and large protestations to have us love them if they killed you.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: What us ?

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Who we ?

sp.speaker: Flo:
